awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities – Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) provides support to principal investigators who undertake an institutional self-analysis in preparation of efforts that specifically address institutional transformation.  Institutions are expected to conduct scientific studies that yield results on critical pedagogies and culturally sensitive interventions that contribute to the success of HBCUs in educating African American STEM undergraduates, the likes of which will be broadly disseminated to the scientific community. The project at University of the District of Columbia (UDC) seeks to plan the essential research questions, experimental designs and programmatic activities for developing a Mathematics Teacher Training Institute (MTTI) that would support a larger, institutional initiative for producing more STEM graduates from underserved communities in the region. 

The goal of this project is to establish MTTI at UDC based on the content conceptualization framework and delivery method developed by the Southern Initiative Algebra Project. The institute’s purpose is to equip higher education faculty with tools to train mathematics teachers at the secondary schools that primarily serve underrepresented minority populations in the region.  As such, the institute will also develop professional development training sessions that are grounded in culturally appropriate and responsive STEM pedagogies for mathematics instructors at the middle school, high school and college-level.  The impact of the proposed approach will be evidenced via mathematics outcomes of participating students attending UDC and partnering K-12 schools.  Activities of this project include: formalizing partnerships with area high schools and the Educational Testing Service; training of undergraduate students to serve as mathematics tutors in the UDC partner schools; training of mathematics teachers from partner institutions; and assessment and study of MTTI training strategies. The project will be guided by an external advisory committee.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Award 1952833 ? Project Outcomes Report

 

Project Title:  The All-American Talent Maximization System Initiative [aka The Mathematics Teacher Training Institute (MTTI)]

PD/PI Name:                                                                Ronald Mason,  Principal Investigator

                                                                                       Lawrence Potter Jr.,  Co-Principal Investigator

Recipient Organization:                                             University of the District of Columbia

The National Science Foundation (NSF) project entitled: ?The Mathematics Teacher Training Institute (MTTI)? was awarded to the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) as a planning grant.  The overarching goal was to establish the essential research questions, experimental designs, and programmatic activities for developing the MTTI that would support a larger, institutional initiative for producing more STEM graduates from underserved communities in the region. MTTI was proposed on the content conceptualization framework and delivery method developed by the Southern Initiative Algebra Project (SIAP) to equip higher education faculty with tools to train mathematics teachers at secondary schools that primarily serve underrepresented minority populations in the region.  The project was designed to lay the groundwork to engage Washington, DC-area PK-12 teachers, community members, and UDC faculty and students in better understanding and redressing systemic racism's impact on mathematics education and ensuring that a population of underserved Black PK-12 students have equitable access to skills necessary for 21st century careers.

 

The project was successful in achieving its objectives and accomplished the following:

1)      Establishing collaboration agreements with the DC Public School System (DCPS), the DC Department of Energy and Environment, the Urban Institute, and Anacostia High School.

2)      Developing a comprehensive plan for MTTI with DCPS teachers, UDC mathematics and teacher education faculty, and SIAP staff.

3)      Obtained permission to designate the MTTI as the ?Katherine G. Johnson Mathematics Teacher Training Institute? in honor of the famed female, African-American mathematician Katherine G. Johnson who had a stellar career at NASA-Langley.

4)      Recruiting UDC faculty and DCPS high school teachers and training student peer tutors and conducting a professional development pilot program for some DC mathematics teachers (virtually) during the summer of 2020, and the spring and summer of 2021.

5)      Having teachers use the resources from the workshop during the subsequent academic year and having peer tutors collaborate with the teachers.

The broader impacts of this project lie in the collaboration between UDC mathematics faculty, SIAP staff, DCPS mathematics teachers, and peer tutors in developing ways to teach mathematics with pedagogies that are grounded in a culturally responsive framework. The PIs of the project, with SIAP?s assistance gathered input from the community including parents, teachers, students, and administrators to guide in the planning of MTTI.

The intellectual merit lies in the fact that the planners of MTTI seek to continue to develop a theory at the intersection of mathematics teaching and racial equity to ensure that the experiences and voices of teachers, students, and families most impacted by race-based inequities in learning are included within this theory. The knowledge gained in the planning grant resulted in the submission of a proposal to establish a center for mathematics education research and teacher training to NSF?s Racial Equity in STEM Program in March 2022.
